text: Ancestry Publishing is founded by John Sittner in Salt Lake City. The company eventually publishes over 40 family history magazine titles and genealogy reference books.
Ancestry Publishing releases "The Source," an about 800-page reference guide for genealogical research with chapters written by leading experts in the field, including Loretto Szucs.
Paul Allen and Dan Taggart, two BYU graduates, start a company called Infobases and produce their first product: a set of 10 floppy disks containing digital versions of all the LDS scriptures.
The Ancestry Store is available on Prodigy, one of the first online service providers.

Infobases releases its first genealogy product, the LDS Family History Suite, which includes family tree software, a collection of LDS pioneer journals and vital records, and a reference database with multiple books from Ancestry Publishing, including "The Source."
Ancestry changes hands. Paul Allen and Dan Taggart buy Ancestry Publishing from John Sittner and combine it with their Infobases business to create a new company called Ancestry.com Inc.
Ancestry splits from Western Standard Publishing, the company under which it was initially organized.

Ancestry completes its first $12 million investment round, with investments from Intel Corp., Wasatch Venture Fund Inc. and the capital arm of CMGI. Ancestry moves its headquarters to San Francisco to position itself among other growing tech companies. Venture capitalists, who now hold a majority of board seats, bring in a new CEO.  Curt Allen, Paul Allenâ€™s brother, is replaced by Greg Ballard, a businessman with experience taking companies public.
While Ancestry is preparing to go public, the dot-com bubble bursts, and Ancestry is forced to restructure and make cuts.
Ancestry reaches the milestone of one billion records. The company begins to expand internationally, with the debut of Ancestry.co.uk.
